 NO. That is incorrect. I've told you multiple times to think about what you're saying, but you refuse. I'll put it in simple doxastic logic for you.

 If your definition of god involves supernatural powers or qualities, then definition of god is a logical contradiction. It's the same as claiming 
 "Prove that all circular squares have four corners."
 It's a nonsensical question, it's a logical contradiction.
 
 Supernatural is defined as "beyond the observable universe".
 Which is, not knowable, by definition. You then claim "I know something of the unknowable", a logical contradiction.
 
 Logically, there are no contradictions.
 
 It doesn't just apply to god either, a great many proposed "insightful" or "philosophical" questions are bogus logical contradictions. You don't prove existence or non-existence of god, you don't get to even rationally have that discussion. If your claim involves knowledge of the unknowable, your contradiction is thrown out as fallacy. We aren't discussing thoughts/concepts in the mind, we're talking about people claiming a god exists/created the universe, etc., etc., a god of reality.
 
 Making claims as true, about things which we define as "unobservable", or "unknowable", is contradictory, in that everything we know, is through observation, either direct or indirect, in the universe. These claims about knowledge of things outside the universe, or outside of reason, or outside of logic, or outside of observation, are all logical contradictions. Knowledge itself requires justification, and again, you cannot say you have knowledge of "something that cannot be proven true or false". It's a contradiction.
 
 
 So yes, it then follows that agnosticism is either:
 
 An incorrect position that is founded in ignorance...that is, lacking knowledge of the contradiction they ponder. (see "I don't know")
 
 OR
 
 Intentional denial that they are pondering a contradiction despite evidence to the contrary, which is irrational/illogical/insanity (see theology).
 
 Either way, they are ignorant, either through choice, or by accident. Atheism is the acceptance of the rational/logical, either ignorantly (if somone hasn't bothered justifying their belief), or reasonably, with justification. I prefer justified beliefs. 
 
 Logically, there can be no meaningful claims of knowledge with regards to things beyond knowledge, by definition.

Sure enough, I am an agnostic[-theist].
 

 
 How is this possible? You don't know if god exists, so you assume he must exist? An agnostic is one who admits there is no way to prove that god exists, and a theist is someone who believes in god. Aren't those contradictory?
dreamweaver

How is this possible? You don't know if god exists, so you assume he must exist? An agnostic is one who admits there is no way to prove that god exists, and a theist is someone who believes in god. Aren't those contradictory?

 Quite the contrary. There are several different usages of "agnostic"; essentially here I'm using it as someone who does not know whether God exists. Using know in the strict sense; hence the strict title. A theist is one who believes that God exists; an agnostic-theist is one who believes but does not know.
 
 Don't let the ordinary usage of "know" put you off here. I'm using "know" here as a "true-belief" (some prefer "justified true belief", but won't get into that now). I don't know that when I drop a stone it will hit the ground; I only presume that it will based on empirical evidence and inductive methods; they're both quite fallible and neither provide 100% certainty.
